The discrepancy between college students' self-reported and perceived LLM usage and that of their friends can be explained by a number of plausible factors:

 Due to social desirability bias, students may underreport their own use of LLM in order to avoid being seen as technologically dependent or academically dishonest.  Students may wish to project an image of independence and competence because an excessive reliance on AI is stigmatized.
 In contrast, they may exaggerate their friends' use in an attempt to justify or normalize their own actions.  Mental defenses like "everyone else is doing it" are widespread.
 Absence of precise knowledge
 It's possible that students don't fully comprehend the frequency of LLM usage among their acquaintances.  Their reliance on anecdotal evidence, rumors, or assumptions may be erroneous.
It's possible that they only observe their peers utilizing LLMs in particular contexts, such as brainstorming or editing, and undervalue their application in other domains, like as writing or research.
 Various meanings of "usage"
 It's possible that students will understand "using" an LLM differently.  While some may just think about direct text generation, others may also think about research, summarizing, or editing using LLMs.
 A student may overestimate a friend's use based on their perception of use, while underestimating their own use due to these disparate definitions.
 Students may project their own worries or anxiety over the use of LLMs onto their friends because they believe that others use them more regularly.
they might not know well enough if their friends use it.

The gap likely comes from social desirability bias—students may underreport their own use of LLMs to appear more independent while assuming others rely on them more. Additionally, perception gaps cause students to misjudge their peers' behavior based on assumptions rather than direct knowledge.

The disparity is most likely caused by social desirability bias, in which students underreport their own LLM usage to look more academically honest, while overestimating their peers' use due to asymmetric perception bias.  Furthermore, students may mistake their awareness of LLM debates or availability for actual usage, distorting their views of others' conduct.  This mismatch demonstrates how individuals frequently misunderstand group standards in relation to their own behavior.
open-code: SDB, academic integrity, overest., AI discussion priming, info asymmetry
